entry.title: Batch Regex operations: performance in python
entry.summary: Batch regex performance benchmarks: iteration vs pandas.apply vs pandas built-in regex
entry.content:
There was a discussion recently on whether it is better to use pandas native interface to regex over iterating; As I've been able to imagine even more different angles of attack (say, using regex in SQL, or merging all patterns into one), I decided to check out them all and see how performance is different

TL;DR;¶

  • slightly concize version of SE.concessions. (2 min 42 sec +/- 6 sec)
  • merged patterns in each deck and precompiled them (2min 45s ± 1.26 s)
  • Next, we checked how apply behaves (2min 44s ± 280 ms)
  • as well as pandas native str.contains (2min 39s ± 4 s)
  • we also tried to use dask to leverage our multiple cores (3min 7s ± 31.2 s) on 3 cores
  • and finally, used SQL regex implementations to run computations on the server - was too long to wait
  • In short, none of the attempts resulted in any significant improvement, likely because all of them use optimized C code under the hood, anyway. Yet, vectorized computations results in a way cleaner code.
  • Dask's overhead resulted in significant increase for this amount of data.
  • Using regex as part of SQL query leads to a very long querying time - of course, with the advantage of machine-independent results
In [1]:
import pandas as pd
import re
from SE.sql import _get_DF
In [2]:
from tqdm import tqdm
tqdm.pandas()
In [3]:
Q = '''SELECT description, price FROM rentals WHERE
       description IS NOT NULL AND
       created_at < '2018-01-01' AND created_at > '2015-12-31' '''
rentals = _get_DF(Q)
In [4]:
print(f'Got {len(rentals):,.0f} listings')

Got 548,159 listings
In [5]:
rentals['description'] = rentals['description'].str.lower()

I.I Slightly shorter implementation of SE.concessions¶

In [44]:
# Patterns for each month (needed for month X free)
calendar = '(jan(uary)?)|(feb(ruary)?)|(mar(ch)?)|(apr(il)?)|(may)|(june?)|'+\
           '(july?)|(aug(ust))|(sept?(ember)?)|(oct(ober)?)|(nov(ember)?)|'+\
           '(dec(ember)?)'

# Different ways to state "month"
month = f'((mo?n?th_?s?_?)|(mo\.?s?\.?)|(%s))' % calendar

# Patterns to determine if rent is discounted, and/or a net effective rent exists
rent_patterns = ['(%s|(weeks)|(rent))\s*(rent)?\s*(is)?\s*(are)?\s*((free)|(off(\.|\s))|(\son\s)|(op(\.|\s))|(concession)|(promotion))' % month,
                 'free\s*((13th)|(thirteenth))?\s*((%s)|(weeks)|(rent))' % month,
                 'net effective',
                 'rent incentive'
                ]


cash_patterns = ['((gift)|(prepaid)|(amazon))\s+card',
                 'free ((.*hd\s?tv)|(amazon prime)|(netflix)|(storage)|(gym membership))',
                 '((cash)|(\$[0-9]?)) (incentive)|(move in bonus)',
                 'uber credit']

deposit_patterns = ['((reduced)|(no)) (security )?deposit']
In [34]:
patterns = {'rent':rent_patterns, 
            "cash": cash_patterns,
            'deposit': deposit_patterns}

def get_rental_concession(description):
    '''given a rental listing description, determine whether listing contains
        one or more concessions and what type of concessions it contains

    Args:
        description(str): listing description
    Returns:
        ctypes: list of categories of concession contained
    '''
    tags = set()
    
    for k, pattern_deck in patterns.items():
        for pattern in pattern_deck:
            if re.search(pattern, description):
                tags.add(k)
                break
    
    if tags:
        return tags

(and create a benchmark to check our new code against)

In [48]:
%%timeit -n1 -r2
tags = {}
for i, el in tqdm(rentals['description'].iteritems()):
    tags[i] = get_rental_concession(el)

T = pd.Series(tags)

548159it [02:48, 3250.46it/s]
548159it [02:35, 3535.03it/s]

2min 42s ± 6.79 s per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 2 runs, 1 loop each)

let also store one in order to compare with other results

In [49]:
tags = {}
for i, el in rentals['description'].iteritems():
    tags[i] = get_rental_concession(el)

T = pd.Series(tags)
In [50]:
T[T.notnull()].head(10)
Out[50]:
39       {rent}
40       {rent}
41       {rent}
42       {rent}
43       {rent}
44       {rent}
46    {deposit}
62       {rent}
64       {rent}
98       {rent}
dtype: object

1.2 Now, pattern decks are nice to read, but perhaps we can merge them into one pattern and pre-compute?¶

In [115]:
patterns = {'rent':rent_patterns, 
            "cash": cash_patterns,
            'deposit': deposit_patterns}

PATTERNS = {k: "|".join(["({})".format(el)for el in v]) for k, v in patterns.items()}
In [60]:
PATTERNS2 = {k:re.compile(v) for k, v in PATTERNS.items()}
In [10]:
def get_rental_concession_2(description):
    '''given a rental listing description, determine whether listing contains
        one or more concessions and what type of concessions it contains

    Args:
        description(str): listing description
    Returns:
        ctypes: list of categories of concession contained
    '''    
    tags = {k for k, p in PATTERNS2.items() if re.search(p, description)}
    
    if tags:
        return tags

Note that this is slightly unfair as we also declare patterns dict once, and use set comprehension instead of iteration

In [11]:
%%timeit -n1 -r2
tags = {}
for i, el in tqdm(rentals['description'].iteritems()):
    tags[i] = get_rental_concession_2(el)

T2 = pd.Series(tags)

548159it [02:43, 3345.53it/s]
548159it [02:46, 3294.80it/s]

2min 45s ± 1.26 s per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 2 runs, 1 loop each)

It seems that there is no difference at all... but function is definitely more consise

In [12]:
# tags = {}
# for i, el in rentals['description'].iteritems():
#     tags[i] = get_rental_concession_2(el)

# T2 = pd.Series(tags)

2. Lets now try using Apply instead¶

In [13]:
%%timeit -n1 -r2
T3 = rentals['description'].progress_apply(get_rental_concession_2)  # replace `progress_apply` with `apply` if you don't use tqdm

100%|██████████| 548159/548159 [02:44<00:00, 3339.04it/s]
100%|██████████| 548159/548159 [02:44<00:00, 3327.68it/s]
2min 44s ± 280 ms per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 2 runs, 1 loop each)























It seems to takes absolutely the same amount of time, althrough way easier to read :-)

















3. Vectorising¶












In [14]:



    


def get_rental_concession_vec(dSeries):
    '''given a rental listing description, determine whether listing contains
        one or more concessions and what type of concessions it contains

    Args:
        description(str): listing description
    Returns:
        ctypes: list of categories of concession contained
    '''
    return pd.DataFrame({k:dSeries.str.contains(p) for k, p in PATTERNS2.items()})

















In [15]:



    


%%timeit -n1 -r2
T4 = get_rental_concession_vec(rentals['description'])


























/Users/philippk/anaconda3/envs/py36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ipykernel_launcher.py:10: UserWarning: This pattern has match groups. To actually get the groups, use str.extract.
  # Remove the CWD from sys.path while we load stuff.

















2min 39s ± 4 s per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 2 runs, 1 loop each)



















In [19]:



    


T4 = get_rental_concession_vec(rentals['description'])
T4[T4.any(1)].head()




















Out[19]:











  
    

      
      rent
      cash
      deposit
    

  
  
    

      39
      True
      False
      False
    

    

      40
      True
      False
      False
    

    

      41
      True
      False
      False
    

    

      42
      True
      False
      False
    

    

      43
      True
      False
      False
    

  


























4. What if we use dask to leverage our N cores?¶












In [22]:



    


from dask import dataframe as dd

















In [23]:



    


mr = dd.from_pandas(rentals, npartitions=3)

















In [28]:



    


%%timeit -n1 -r2
concessions = mr['description'].map_partitions(get_rental_concession_vec)
T5 = concessions.compute()


























/Users/philippk/anaconda3/envs/py36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ipykernel_launcher.py:10: UserWarning: This pattern has match groups. To actually get the groups, use str.extract.
  # Remove the CWD from sys.path while we load stuff.
/Users/philippk/anaconda3/envs/py36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ipykernel_launcher.py:10: UserWarning: This pattern has match groups. To actually get the groups, use str.extract.
  # Remove the CWD from sys.path while we load stuff.

















3min 7s ± 31.2 s per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 2 runs, 1 loop each)























So this was way slower in this case. Probably this can save some time if there is more than a million descriptions.

















5. using regex in SQL query itself?¶












In [74]:



    


Q = '''SELECT description, price,
       description REGEXP '{rent}' as 'rent',
       description REGEXP  '{cash}' as 'cash', 
       description REGEXP '{deposit}' as 'deposit'
       FROM rentals WHERE (1
       AND description IS NOT NULL
       AND created_at < '2018-01-01' AND created_at > '2015-12-31' );'''.format(rent=PATTERNS['rent'],
                                                                                cash=PATTERNS['cash'],
                                                                                deposit=PATTERNS['deposit'])





















takes too long...¶












In [78]:



    


## takes too long...

# %%timeit -n1 -r1 
# df2 = _get_DF(Q)





















Compare results¶












In [87]:



    


import altair as alt

















In [129]:



    


results = pd.DataFrame([
    {"method":'SE.concessions',"mean": 2*60 +42, 'std': 6.79 },
    {"method":'pre-compiled',"mean": 2*60 +45, 'std': 1.26 },
    {"method":'pd.apply',"mean": 2*60 +44, 'std': .28 },
    {"method":'vectorised',"mean": 2*60 +39, 'std': 4 },
    {"method":'dask-3',"mean": 3*60 + 7, 'std': 31.2 }
])


results['low'] = results['mean'] - results['std']
results['high'] = results['mean'] + results['std']

















In [130]:



    


bar = alt.Chart(results).mark_point().encode(
    x=alt.Color('method:N'),
    y='mean:Q',
    color=alt.Color('method:N')
)

rule = alt.Chart(results).mark_rule().encode(
    x='method:N',
    y=alt.Y(
        'low',
        scale=alt.Scale(zero=False),
        axis=alt.Axis(title='performance, sec')
    ),
    y2=alt.Y2('high'),
    color=alt.Color('method:N'),
    size=alt.value(10),
    opacity=alt.value(.3)
    
).properties(
    title='Text processing'
)

bar + rule




















Out[130]:






























Additional Links¶
















flashtext - faster than regex for hundreds of search words

entry.title: StreetEasy Price Index Code
entry.summary: StreetEasy fast implementation of Case-Shiller Home Price Indices, written in python.
entry.content:
Here is a toy example using closings data from Downtown Manhattan from 1995 to present. All code needed should be contained within the zipped directory. Code was developed for Python 3.6, but should be backward compatible. Admittedly, exponential smoothing is not the best method for smoothing a non-stationary time series, but that's an issue for another day. Please keep db credentials close hold.

In [1]:
import numpy as np
import pylab as plt
import pandas as pd
import warnings
import pickle
%matplotlib inline

from pymysql import connect

from preprocess import process_transactions, get_feature_matrix, get_date_sequence
from pi import calculate_index

warnings.simplefilter(action='ignore', category=FutureWarning)

start = 1995
In [2]:
df = pd.read_csv('raw_df.csv')
df = df.drop(columns='Unnamed: 0')
In [3]:
df.loc[:, 'trxnDate'] = pd.to_datetime(df['trxnDate'])

match_df = process_transactions(df)

XR, YR, DR = get_feature_matrix(match_df, start_year=start)
resultR = calculate_index(XR,YR,DR)
results_exp = pd.ewma(resultR, com=6)

ax2 = pd.Series(resultR, index=XR.columns).rolling(window=6).mean().plot(alpha=.5, color='r')
ax2 = pd.Series(resultR, index=XR.columns).rolling(window=12).mean().plot(alpha=.5, color='g')
pd.Series(results_exp, index=XR.columns).plot(ax=ax2, color='k')

/Users/grantl/anaconda3/envs/py36/lib/python3.6/site-packages/scipy/linalg/basic.py:1226: RuntimeWarning: internal gelsd driver lwork query error, required iwork dimension not returned. This is likely the result of LAPACK bug 0038, fixed in LAPACK 3.2.2 (released July 21, 2010). Falling back to 'gelss' driver.
  warnings.warn(mesg, RuntimeWarning)
In [4]:
chg = ((results_exp[list(XR.columns).index('_2017-11')]
        /results_exp[list(XR.columns).index('_2012-11')])**(1/5)-1)*100

print('%0.1f%% annual change in Downtown Manhattan sales prices since 2012.' % (chg))

5.1% annual change in Downtown Manhattan sales prices since 2012.
